data: Entella 5 = A1, Entella thanks those who helped in the synoikismos

Bronze tablet, no measurements; rectangular with triangular pediment; border attached by nails on all sides except base; an additional strip divides the pediment from the rectangular body; 3 nail holes, at top middle, bottom right, bottom left.

Lines 1-5 are roughly centred in the tympanon of the tablet. From line 6, the text is sited on the main rectangular body of the tablet. The left hand margin is ‘justified’, the right not. Line 15 exceeds the left hand margin by one letter space; the implication of both the position of the initial kappa and its form would seem to be that the engraver initially omitted it.
First Punic War (264-241 BCE), and commonly attributed to the second half of the war.

The tablet is one of 8 illegally looted from the site of Rocca d'Entella, almost certainly in the spring of 1977 from a location in close proximity to the more recently excavated area in the centre of the ancient city in the 'eastern valley'. For the fullest discussion, see Ampolo 2021, esp. 91-93. Ampolo, Magnetto and Porciani 2001 demonstrate that the 8 tablets were preserved for an extended period in a single location, superimposed upon one another, probably in a container (a stone theka?), and were most likely found together also. Although reported, investigated, and published multiple times, the tablet remains unrecovered and in private hands.
Image courtesy of the Centre for the Study of Ancient Documents, Faculty of Classics, University of Oxford

English translation

Jonathan Prag

In the archonship of Artemidoros son of Eielos and Gnaios Oppios, on the new moon of Panamos. Since some of the cities have come to the help of the synoikismos of the city with corn, some having given it to the city as a free gift and some having made it available, and have shown great good will to the people of Entella and have created abundance of corn instead of dearth, resolved by the Council that all those of the cities that have helped the synoikismos of the city with corn or money or anything else are to enjoy good will and equal citizenship with the people of Entella for all time and they shall be invited to the games and to the front seats, and those individuals who have assisted the city with corn for the synoikismos shall be proxenoi of the city of Entella, themselves and their children. Resolved also by the Assembly. The community of the Petrinoi made available 201 medimnoi of wheat. The community of the Kutattarinioi gave as a gift of wheat 60, of barley 51. The community of the Scherinoi(?) gave as a gift of wheat 30, of barley 30. The community of the Makellinoi made available 100 medimnoi of wheat. And the private citizens of the Petrinoi who made corn available were these: Theodoros son of Praton the Sanneian of wheat 150; Aischylos son of Praton the Sanneian of wheat 120; Herakleios son of Herakleidas of wheat 100; Arimnastos son of Simos 50; Sosandros son of Ariston of wheat 50; Minatos Corvios the Mamertine of barley 30. The archons are to write this decree on a bronze plaque and exhibit it in the council-chamber.

Italian translation

Jonathan Prag

commentary

The text of Lewis was at least partially based upon photographs taken pre-cleaning; and the initial texts of Nenci / Nenci and Asheri were derivative of Lewis' original transcription. The bibliography is intended to cover principal editions only. For a recent historical discussion, elucidating the First Punic War context, see Lombardo, Mario. 2018. «Entella tra i Cartaginesi e i Romani, ovvero da chi erano stati espulsi gli Entellini». In Munus Laetitiae. Studi miscellanei offerti a Maria Letizia Lazzarini, a cura di Francesco Camia, Lavinio Del Monaco, e Michela Nocita, 2:485–98. Rome: Sapienza Universita Editrice. https://doi.org/10.13133/9788893770736; and now Souza 2024.

English translation

Jonathan Prag

In the archonship of Artemidoros son of Eielos and Gnaios Oppios, on the new moon of Panamos. Since some of the cities have come to the help of the synoikismos of the city with corn, some having given it to the city as a free gift and some having made it available, and have shown great good will to the people of Entella and have created abundance of corn instead of dearth, resolved by the Council that all those of the cities that have helped the synoikismos of the city with corn or money or anything else are to enjoy good will and equal citizenship with the people of Entella for all time and they shall be invited to the games and to the front seats, and those individuals who have assisted the city with corn for the synoikismos shall be proxenoi of the city of Entella, themselves and their children. Resolved also by the Assembly. The community of the Petrinoi made available 201 medimnoi of wheat. The community of the Kutattarinioi gave as a gift of wheat 60, of barley 51. The community of the Scherinoi(?) gave as a gift of wheat 30, of barley 30. The community of the Makellinoi made available 100 medimnoi of wheat. And the private citizens of the Petrinoi who made corn available were these: Theodoros son of Praton the Sanneian of wheat 150; Aischylos son of Praton the Sanneian of wheat 120; Herakleios son of Herakleidas of wheat 100; Arimnastos son of Simos 50; Sosandros son of Ariston of wheat 50; Minatos Corvios the Mamertine of barley 30. The archons are to write this decree on a bronze plaque and exhibit it in the council-chamber.

commentary

The text of Lewis was at least partially based upon photographs taken pre-cleaning; and the initial texts of Nenci / Nenci and Asheri were derivative of Lewis' original transcription. The bibliography is intended to cover principal editions only. For a recent historical discussion, elucidating the First Punic War context, see Lombardo, Mario. 2018. «Entella tra i Cartaginesi e i Romani, ovvero da chi erano stati espulsi gli Entellini». In Munus Laetitiae. Studi miscellanei offerti a Maria Letizia Lazzarini, a cura di Francesco Camia, Lavinio Del Monaco, e Michela Nocita, 2:485–98. Rome: Sapienza Universita Editrice. https://doi.org/10.13133/9788893770736; and now Souza 2024.

Entella 5 = A1, Entella thanks those who helped in the synoikismos Jonathan Prag Jonathan Prag John Fell OUP Research Fund ERC Advanced Grant no.885040 Jonathan Prag original data collection and editing James Cummings EpiDoc template development James Chartrand site construction and encoding Valeria Vitale editing of geo data Michael Metcalfe museum data collection system automated or batch processes Simona Stoyanova standardisation of template and tidying up encoding I.Sicily ISic030298 697651 154889 http://sicily.classics.ox.ac.uk/inscription/ISic030298 Licensed under a Creative Commons-Attribution 4.0 licence Unknown private location Ancient Greek

Bronze tablet, no measurements; rectangular with triangular pediment; border attached by nails on all sides except base; an additional strip divides the pediment from the rectangular body; 3 nail holes, at top middle, bottom right, bottom left.

bronze lamina

Lines 1-5 are roughly centred in the tympanon of the tablet. From line 6, the text is sited on the main rectangular body of the tablet. The left hand margin is ‘justified’, the right not. Line 15 exceeds the left hand margin by one letter space; the implication of both the position of the initial kappa and its form would seem to be that the engraver initially omitted it.

engraved

Line 1 Interlineation not measured Entella Rocca d'Entella 37.77889, 13.11509 First Punic War (264-241 BCE), and commonly attributed to the second half of the war. The tablet is one of 8 illegally looted from the site of Rocca d'Entella, almost certainly in the spring of 1977 from a location in close proximity to the more recently excavated area in the centre of the ancient city in the 'eastern valley'. For the fullest discussion, see Ampolo 2021, esp. 91-93. Ampolo, Magnetto and Porciani 2001 demonstrate that the 8 tablets were preserved for an extended period in a single location, superimposed upon one another, probably in a container (a stone theka?), and were most likely found together also. Although reported, investigated, and published multiple times, the tablet remains unrecovered and in private hands.37.7738798,13.124137 none

In the archonship of Artemidoros son of Eielos and Gnaios Oppios, on the new moon of Panamos. Since some of the cities have come to the help of the synoikismos of the city with corn, some having given it to the city as a free gift and some having made it available, and have shown great good will to the people of Entella and have created abundance of corn instead of dearth, resolved by the Council that all those of the cities that have helped the synoikismos of the city with corn or money or anything else are to enjoy good will and equal citizenship with the people of Entella for all time and they shall be invited to the games and to the front seats, and those individuals who have assisted the city with corn for the synoikismos shall be proxenoi of the city of Entella, themselves and their children. Resolved also by the Assembly. The community of the Petrinoi made available 201 medimnoi of wheat. The community of the Kutattarinioi gave as a gift of wheat 60, of barley 51. The community of the Scherinoi(?) gave as a gift of wheat 30, of barley 30. The community of the Makellinoi made available 100 medimnoi of wheat. And the private citizens of the Petrinoi who made corn available were these: Theodoros son of Praton the Sanneian of wheat 150; Aischylos son of Praton the Sanneian of wheat 120; Herakleios son of Herakleidas of wheat 100; Arimnastos son of Simos 50; Sosandros son of Ariston of wheat 50; Minatos Corvios the Mamertine of barley 30. The archons are to write this decree on a bronze plaque and exhibit it in the council-chamber.
